questions.question: Change to indirect speech: Shreya said, 'I watched an interesting programme last evening.'
questions.answer: Shreya said that she had watched an interesting programme the previous evening.
questions.explanation: Simple past 'watched' changes to past perfect 'had watched'. 'I' changes to 'she'. 'Last evening' changes to 'the previous evening'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: Garima said, 'My best friend is Vinita.'
questions.answer: Garima said that her best friend was Vinita.
questions.explanation: 'My' changes to 'her'. 'Is' changes to 'was'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: The old man said, 'Patience brings its own rewards.'
questions.answer: The old man said that patience brings its own rewards.
questions.explanation: This is a universal truth/proverb, so the tense does not change.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: The doctor said, 'Nobody can recover without taking medicines.'
questions.answer: The doctor said that nobody could recover without taking medicines.
questions.explanation: 'Can' changes to 'could' in indirect speech.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: Mother said, 'The gardener has taken excellent care of the flowerbeds.'
questions.answer: Mother said that the gardener had taken excellent care of the flowerbeds.
questions.explanation: Present perfect 'has taken' changes to past perfect 'had taken'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: The shopkeeper said, 'I will open the shop as soon as possible.'
questions.answer: The shopkeeper said that he would open the shop as soon as possible.
questions.explanation: 'I' changes to 'he'. 'Will' changes to 'would'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: The passengers said, 'We have waited long enough for the train to arrive.'
questions.answer: The passengers said that they had waited long enough for the train to arrive.
questions.explanation: 'We' changes to 'they'. Present perfect 'have waited' changes to past perfect 'had waited'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: The pilot said, 'We have to be careful during winter.'
questions.answer: The pilot said that they had to be careful during winter.
questions.explanation: 'We' changes to 'they'. 'Have to' changes to 'had to'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: The girls said that they were tired of watching television.
questions.answer: The girls said, 'We are tired of watching television.'
questions.explanation: 'They' changes back to 'we'. 'Were tired' changes back to 'are tired'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: The carpenter said that he had completed the order.
questions.answer: The carpenter said, 'I have completed the order.'
questions.explanation: 'He' changes back to 'I'. Past perfect 'had completed' changes back to present perfect 'have completed'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: Grandmother said that an honest deed is worthy of appreciation.
questions.answer: Grandmother said, 'An honest deed is worthy of appreciation.'
questions.explanation: This is a universal truth, so the tense remains unchanged. Just add quotation marks.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: Narendra said that he would try his best to meet his mother's expectations.
questions.answer: Narendra said, 'I will try my best to meet my mother's expectations.'
questions.explanation: 'He' changes to 'I'. 'Would' changes back to 'will'. 'His' changes to 'my'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: The lawyer said that he was sure of winning the case.
questions.answer: The lawyer said, 'I am sure of winning the case.'
questions.explanation: 'He' changes to 'I'. 'Was' changes back to 'am'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: The tourists said that they had enjoyed going round the historical city.
questions.answer: The tourists said, 'We have enjoyed going round the historical city.'
questions.explanation: 'They' changes to 'we'. Past perfect 'had enjoyed' changes back to present perfect 'have enjoyed'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: Mother said that all the vegetables were spoilt.
questions.answer: Mother said, 'All the vegetables are spoilt.'
questions.explanation: 'Were' changes back to 'are'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: The principal said that she was proud of the progress made by the school.
questions.answer: The principal said, 'I am proud of the progress made by the school.'
questions.explanation: 'She' changes to 'I'. 'Was' changes back to 'am'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: The girl said to her mother, 'I have cleaned my room.'
questions.answer: The girl told her mother that she had cleaned her room.
questions.explanation: 'Said to' becomes 'told'. 'I' changes to 'she'. 'Have cleaned' changes to 'had cleaned'. 'My' changes to 'her'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: My boss said to me, 'I am happy with your work.'
questions.answer: My boss told me that he was happy with my work.
questions.explanation: 'Said to me' becomes 'told me'. 'I' changes to 'he'. 'Am' changes to 'was'. 'Your' changes to 'my'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: Grandfather said to Aunt Latika, 'I liked your story.'
questions.answer: Grandfather told Aunt Latika that he had liked her story.
questions.explanation: 'Said to' becomes 'told'. 'I' changes to 'he'. 'Liked' changes to 'had liked'. 'Your' changes to 'her'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: Harish said to his friend, 'We can win the match if we do our best.'
questions.answer: Harish told his friend that they could win the match if they did their best.
questions.explanation: 'Said to' becomes 'told'. 'We' changes to 'they'. 'Can' changes to 'could'. 'Do' changes to 'did'. 'Our' changes to 'their'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: The author said to the reporter, 'I have not decided on the title of my new story.'
questions.answer: The author told the reporter that he had not decided on the title of his new story.
questions.explanation: 'Said to' becomes 'told'. 'I' changes to 'he'. 'Have not decided' changes to 'had not decided'. 'My' changes to 'his'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: The policeman said to the stranger, 'You will find your way if you have the directions.'
questions.answer: The policeman told the stranger that he would find his way if he had the directions.
questions.explanation: 'Said to' becomes 'told'. 'You' changes to 'he'. 'Will' changes to 'would'. 'Your' changes to 'his'. 'Have' changes to 'had'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: Nikita said, 'I really like the green dress Mother has bought.'
questions.answer: Nikita said that she really liked the green dress Mother had bought.
questions.explanation: 'I' changes to 'she'. 'Like' changes to 'liked'. 'Has bought' changes to 'had bought'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: I said, 'He was helping the people injured in the accident.'
questions.answer: I said that he had been helping the people injured in the accident.
questions.explanation: Past continuous 'was helping' changes to past perfect continuous 'had been helping'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: Priya says, 'I will be back soon.'
questions.answer: Priya says that she will be back soon.
questions.explanation: When the reporting verb is in present tense ('says'), there is no change of tense in indirect speech. Only 'I' changes to 'she'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: Mahima said to you, 'He will be declared the champion this year.'
questions.answer: Mahima told you that he would be declared the champion that year.
questions.explanation: 'Said to' becomes 'told'. 'Will' changes to 'would'. 'This year' changes to 'that year'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: I said, 'I went to Switzerland last year.'
questions.answer: I said that I had gone to Switzerland the previous year.
questions.explanation: Simple past 'went' changes to past perfect 'had gone'. 'Last year' changes to 'the previous year'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: Manoj said to me, 'I am very busy now.'
questions.answer: Manoj told me that he was very busy then.
questions.explanation: 'Said to me' becomes 'told me'. 'I' changes to 'he'. 'Am' changes to 'was'. 'Now' changes to 'then'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: The teacher said to us, 'I will be taking a test on conjunctions tomorrow.'
questions.answer: The teacher told us that she would be taking a test on conjunctions the next day.
questions.explanation: 'Said to us' becomes 'told us'. 'I' changes to 'she'. 'Will' changes to 'would'. 'Tomorrow' changes to 'the next day'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: Swati will say, 'Shreya plays the piano very well.'
questions.answer: Swati will say that Shreya plays the piano very well.
questions.explanation: When the reporting verb is in future tense ('will say'), there is no change of tense in indirect speech.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: The guests will say, 'The arrangements are excellent.'
questions.answer: The guests will say that the arrangements are excellent.
questions.explanation: When the reporting verb is in future tense ('will say'), there is no change of tense in indirect speech.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: Neeraj said to the teacher, 'I have completed the project I was working on.'
questions.answer: Neeraj told the teacher that he had completed the project he had been working on.
questions.explanation: 'Said to' becomes 'told'. 'I' changes to 'he'. 'Have completed' changes to 'had completed'. 'Was working' changes to 'had been working'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: Rita said to her father, 'The museum is closed on Monday.'
questions.answer: Rita told her father that the museum was closed on Monday.
questions.explanation: 'Said to' becomes 'told'. 'Is' changes to 'was'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: The manager said to the clerk, 'We have to complete the work by the end of this week.'
questions.answer: The manager told the clerk that they had to complete the work by the end of that week.
questions.explanation: 'Said to' becomes 'told'. 'We' changes to 'they'. 'Have to' changes to 'had to'. 'This week' changes to 'that week'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Interrogative): Mother said to Rohan, 'Why are you feeling so nervous?'
questions.answer: Mother asked Rohan why he was feeling so nervous.
questions.explanation: For wh-questions, 'said to' becomes 'asked'. Keep the question word 'why'. 'Are' changes to 'was'. 'You' changes to 'he'. Remove the question mark.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Imperative): The zoo-keeper said to the visitors, 'Please do not tease the animals.'
questions.answer: The zoo-keeper requested the visitors not to tease the animals.
questions.explanation: 'Please' indicates a request, so use 'requested'. Negative imperative uses 'not to + verb'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Exclamatory): The hero said, 'Hurrah! The film is a grand success.'
questions.answer: The hero exclaimed with joy that the film was a grand success.
questions.explanation: 'Hurrah' expresses joy, so use 'exclaimed with joy'. 'Is' changes to 'was'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Interrogative): Richa said to her brother, 'Where have you hidden my paintbrushes?'
questions.answer: Richa asked her brother where he had hidden her paintbrushes.
questions.explanation: For wh-questions, use 'asked'. Keep 'where'. 'Have hidden' changes to 'had hidden'. 'You' changes to 'he'. 'My' changes to 'her'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: The guard said, 'All the gates to the auditorium are locked.'
questions.answer: The guard said that all the gates to the auditorium were locked.
questions.explanation: 'Are' changes to 'were'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Interrogative): Manish said to the shopkeeper, 'Have you packed my purchases?'
questions.answer: Manish asked the shopkeeper if he had packed his purchases.
questions.explanation: For yes/no questions, use 'asked if/whether'. 'Have packed' changes to 'had packed'. 'You' changes to 'he'. 'My' changes to 'his'.
